mental_model.explanation: Old CSS (tables/fixed width) was like putting water in a glass box; if the screen got smaller, it overflowed or broke. Modern Responsive CSS is like putting water in a balloon; it expands and contracts to fit the space available using Flexbox, Grid, and Media Queries.

real_world_use_cases: Ensuring the app looks good on Mobile, Tablet, and Desktop.
Scoping styles to components to prevent side effects.

related_concepts.relationship: Design philosophy where you write styles for small screens first, then expand.
Naming convention for traditional CSS to avoid clashes.

concepts.name: Modern Responsive Techniques
concepts.description: Tools to make layouts adapt to viewport size.
details: Flexbox: One-dimensional layout (rows OR columns). Great for alignment.
CSS Grid: Two-dimensional layout (rows AND columns). Great for page structure.
Media Queries: Applying styles based on breakpoints (`@media (min-width: 768px)`).

concepts.name: CSS-in-JS
concepts.description: Writing CSS directly inside JavaScript components (e.g., Styled Components, Emotion).
details: Pros: Scoped styles (no name collisions), Dynamic styling based on props, painless deletion (delete component = delete styles).
Cons: Runtime performance cost, larger bundle size, steeper learning curve.

concepts.name: Traditional CSS / CSS Modules
details: Pros: Zero runtime cost, cacheable by browser, separate concerns.
Cons: Global namespace (unless using Modules), harder to maintain in large apps without conventions (BEM).

concepts.name: Utility-First CSS (Tailwind)
concepts.description: Using pre-defined utility classes directly in HTML.
details: Pros: Extremely fast development, consistent design system, no dead CSS.
Cons: 'Ugly' HTML clutter, learning curve for class names.
